forecast.review: Both forecasters largely align with my base case and added a couple of useful nuances. Forecaster 2 emphasized the ongoing possibility of confidential treatment even for highly liquid mega-cap names, which matters because the question resolves strictly on what’s reported in the Q1 13F. That slightly lowers the chance of a Yes even if a position exists. They also noted Berkshire’s cash pile and concentration in Apple as a mild force toward diversification (a small push toward Yes). Forecaster 3 highlighted Berkshire’s recent net-selling/cash-buildup posture and reiterated that any active accumulation could still be masked under confidentiality—again tilting toward No on this specific filing. The BYD–Tesla conflict point is a small but consistent negative for TSLA. I find the confidentiality angle, given Berkshire’s recent use of it (e.g., Chubb), the most convincing incremental argument that I had underweighted.
forecast.rationale: We’re about a week from the 13F. The base rate of Berkshire initiating brand-new Magnificent 7 positions is low; when they have ventured beyond Apple/Amazon it’s typically via Todd/Ted and in modest size. Their recent stance—trimming risk, building cash, and caution on lofty tech valuations—reduces the likelihood of a fresh, disclosed stake in Alphabet/Meta/Microsoft/Nvidia/Tesla. Name-by-name, Tesla remains extremely unlikely; Nvidia and Microsoft face valuation/optics hurdles; Alphabet/Meta are the most plausible but still constrained by valuation and lack of prior signals. Critically for this question, even if a buy occurred, the chance of confidential treatment obscuring it this quarter isn’t negligible, which lowers the probability of a Yes on the Q1 13F specifically. Balancing a small positive from potential diversification against a stronger negative from confidentiality/use-of-cash posture, I trim my estimate slightly. I move from 12% to 11%.
